text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. I have the ambitious goal of presenting

12 literary devices. I can't do this in the 
blink of an eye, but I promise I won't be as

slow as molasses. Hopefully, by the time we're 
through, you'll love these wonderful, witty,

yet wacky literary devices, and you'll understand 
which ones I just used. Let's get started.

Have you ever faced rejection? 
If you ask someone out on a date,

and they give a polite excuse each time, '"Oh, 
I'm going out of town." "I have family visiting."

I think you're failing to read between the 
lines. The person isn't interested in having

dinner with you. They're not saying this directly; 
you just have to understand what isn't being said.

To read between the lines is an idiom. It's a 
figurative expression, a colorful way of speaking.

Idioms are used in spoken and written 
English. They're common in movies,

in novels, in the news, and in conversation. 
It's important to understand them,

but that doesn't mean you have to 
learn every idiom under the sun.

You also shouldn't try to use 
idioms in every single sentence.
That won't make your English sound more natural.

Remember that some idioms are used only 
in a particular variety of English.

Americans don't understand every 
British idiom and vice versa. Also,

there could be idioms that sound outdated to a 
younger generation. "What do you say, Dorothy? Do
you want to hit the hay, as they say on the farm?"

Similes and metaphors are creative ways to 
make comparisons. They're common in poetry,

but that doesn't mean that poets have a monopoly 
on them. You can use them too. Similes are

comparisons that use "like" or "as." Metaphors are 
direct comparisons. I'll give you some examples,

and then you can tell me whether 
there are similes or metaphors.

Certain things are like 
riding a bike. Time is money.

The child ate all the cookies and 
then sat there as innocent as a lamb.

My neighbor has become a thorn in my 
side with her constant complaints.
Wow! You look like a million dollars!

Similes and metaphors allow us to be creative and 
colorful, but also concise. They should be easy to

understand. We shouldn't have to explain them. The 
similes and metaphors I just shared are common. If

you use them, you'll be understood. "I'm clear. I'm 
clear as a bell." An analogy is similar to a simile

or a metaphor because we're making a comparison, 
but an analogy has a purpose. We use analogies

to explain things. "Douglas, you are stem. 
Katya, you are petal. Together we make flower."

How should a man and a woman skate in figure 
skating? Like petals on a stem. Together

they form a flower that blooms in beauty. A 
colorful way of putting it, right? "Douglas,

you are stem. Katya, you are petal. Together 
we make flower. Hyperbole appears in spoken

and written English. Some people like to make a 
mountain out of a molehill. It's just their style

to exaggerate. They use hyperbole. Telling you 
that there are a million reasons why you should

study with me is an exaggeration. I can probably 
come up with a couple dozen, but not a million. If

you'd like more examples, watch my lesson on 
hyperbole. You'll see how similes and idioms

kind of mix in with hyperbole. "Don't tell Marilla 
that I said anything. She'll say I'm interfering."

"Wild horses couldn't drag it from me." Irony is 
something you have to be mature enough to detect.

It can be hard for a young child to 
understand this subtle form of humor.

Irony often has to do with a surprising situation, 
an unexpected outcome. Sometimes we comment on the

irony of a situation. Like, when Steve Jobs got 
fired from Apple and then went back to help the

company and make it great. We can say: Do you see 
the irony? Isn't that ironic? How ironic, right?

Other times irony isn't a surprising 
situation, but rather a contrast between

our words and our true thoughts. Hearing your 
neighbors scream at each other as they argue

may lead you to say, "Well, I guess they feel 
the need to open up and share their feelings."
That kind of understatement is a form of irony.

Sarcasm, in my understanding, is an extension 
of irony. Sarcasm is negative. It's meant to be

insulting or confrontational. Let's say you 
know a guy who was stood up at his wedding,

meaning the bride decided not to go through with 
it. She didn't come. You heartlessly comment,

"I bet that felt bad." The 
guy responds with sarcasm.

"No, it felt really good. Thanks for bringing 
it up, man. You know, my parents died when I

was 10. Would you like to talk about that?" Puns 
are humorous wordplay. Advertisers especially

like to play with what words mean and how words 
sound. I was searching online, and I came across

a Vietnamese restaurant out in California called 
Good Pho You. It made me smile and chuckle.

Good Pho You. That's a play on words. "Pho" is 
the name of the soup, and it sounds a lot like

"for." Good for you. Good Pho You. That's a 
clever and memorable pun. That's good marketing.

If I were in the area, I'd try their Pho soup. 
Puns can make use of homophones. I have a lesson

on that, by the way. I'll put the link in the 
video description. Journalists and reporters

sometimes use puns, like Bill Murray's character 
in Groundhog Day. He gives a report on February

2nd, and he's waiting for the groundhog 
named Phil to make its prediction. "So,

I guess the question we have to ask 
ourselves today is, 'Does Phil feel lucky?'"

"So, I guess the question we have to 
ask ourselves today is, 'Does Phil

feel lucky?'" Parallelism is something I 
usually talk about in the context of grammar

and writing. Parallel structure is 
about having grammatically equal terms

in pairs or a series of items, for example, 
"neither too hard, nor too difficult."

As a literary device, parallelism is about 
using repetition -- repetition of structures

for emphasis. We have parallelism 
in many of our sayings and proverbs.

No pain, no gain. Nothing ventured, nothing 
gained. You'll also hear it in movies.

"We came. We saw. We kicked its ---." You don't 
want to have too much repetition, especially

in your writing, but a small amount can be 
effective. Parallelism can convey an idea clearly.

The delivery can be strong and memorable. 
"We will not go quietly into the night.

We will not vanish without a fight. We're 
going to live on. We're going to survive."

Personification is giving human 
qualities to inanimate objects,

non-human things. I read an example 
at my New Year's Eve livestream.

In Tennyson's poem "Ring Out, Wild Bells," he 
writes, "The year is dying in the night;/ Ring

out, wild bells, and let him die." The poet 
thinks of the passing year as a person dying.

There are some conversational expressions 
that use personification, like "opportunity

knocks." When opportunity knocks, open 
the door. "Fortune smiles on someone."
Fortune was smiling on me the day I met you.

"Opportunity is knocking at the door. 
If you don't want to answer it, fine."

An oxymoron is formed when we put two words 
together, and it seems like they contradict

each other, but instead the meaning is clear and 
strong. In my grammar lesson on intensifiers and

downtoners, I taught the phrase "awfully good." 
It means "really good.' That's an oxymoron.

"She's an awfully good reporter." In one of 
my bonus videos for Patreon members, I taught

ways to organize information. For example, names 
can appear in alphabetical order, from A to Z.

Other times names might be listed in 
random order -- there's no logic to it,

so "random order" is an oxymoron. Listen 
for more oxymorons. "It was the only choice

possible." "Choice" implies two or more options, 
right? So how can we talk about our only choice?

But we do. It means the only thing we can do. 
"Everybody, act natural. Act naturally." If

you're acting, how is it natural or normal? 
But "act naturally" is a common phrase.

Onomatopoeia is a lot of fun, although it's 
a difficult word to spell. I bet you know

some examples already. Here are just a few. 
Boom. Hiss. Zip. Meow. These words imitate the

sounds they describe. The "pitter-patter" 
of raindrops is another good example.

The pitter patter of raindrops is the 
sound of rain as it hits a surface.

Check out my lesson on onomatopoeia to learn more, 
especially animal sounds. Do you know what a dog,

a frog, and a cow say in English? I'll 
put all links in the video description.

Alliteration is our last literary device. 
Americans love to use it especially in names:

Janet Jackson, Ronald Reagan, Marilyn Monroe. 
Alliteration is the use of repetitive sounds.

We usually repeat the first consonant sound, but 
repetition can also be in the middle of a word.

We also like to repeat vowel sounds. 
Alliteration makes a name sound more musical.

When I created some of my levels 
on Patreon, I used alliteration.

After Super Member comes Truly Marvelous 
Member and then Absolutely Amazing Member.

Can you think of any businesses or 
celebrities with alliteration in their names?

"Ned. Ryerson. Needle Nose Ned. 
Ned the Head. Come on, buddy."

We did it! 12 literary devices worth knowing. Look 
out for them. Try using them a bit, and I'll just

be jumping for joy if you decide to like and share 
this video. Remember I have tons of other topics,

so be sure to check out my other playlists. As 
always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Everyone, visit me on Patreon. You 
can join to support my online work,

get live lessons and bonus videos, and some of 
you may even want a monthly one-on-one video call.
Follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.

And don't forget to subscribe. 
Turn on those notifications.
